info.title: Web Requests
info.description: A versatile plugin for getting content from the web, parsing that content in different ways, and overcoming the infamous "September 2021 Knowledge Cutoff!"

post.summary: Scrape content/data from a URL, web page, or endpoint. Including HTML, PDF, JSON, XML, CSV, and images.

url.description: (Required) The URL to scrape or perform a Google search if 'is_search' is set to true. When is_search is set to true, the 'url' parameter will be treated as a search query for Google.

page.description: The page number (of data chunks, not web pages) to retrieve, based on the page_size that was chosen. To request subsequent pages, increment the value of the 'page' parameter, and be sure to send job_id for which you are paginating. For example, to request the second page, set 'page' to 2.

page_size.description: The maximum number of characters that will be returned with each page (chunk). Defaults to 10000, can go higher. It's important to keep in mind the relationship between page_size and page. For example, if you set page_size to 10000 and page to 2, you will receive the second 10000 characters of the content. If you set page_size to 10000 and page to 3, you will receive the third 10000 characters of the content.

is_search.description: Indicates whether the request is a search query. If set to true, the 'url' parameter will be treated as a search query for Google.

follow_links.description: (Optional) Only relevant when 'is_search' is true. Indicates whether to return the content of the search result's underlying page (when true) or just the result's metadata (when false). Default is false.

num_results_to_scrape.description: (Optiona) Only relevant when 'is_search' is true. The number of search results to return. Default is 3.

job_id.description: (Optional) Job ID's are generated when we get your initial request for something new, and are returned in the response data for your reference and so you can either parse the data or paginate through the response pages/chunks. It is recommended to include the job_id's from prior successful responses when requesting subsequent chunks from the same URL to retrieve content from the cached snapshot of the original request.

refresh_cache.description: (Optional) Indicates whether to refresh the cache for the content at the URL in this request. If set to true, a new request to the URL will be made and the cache will be updated. This is useful if you're requesting an endpoint that is frequently updated. Default is false.

no_strip.description: (Optional) Indicates whether to skip the stripping of HTML tags and clutter. Use this flag if you want to preserve the original HTML structure, such as when specifically looking for something in source code. When 'no_strip' is set to false (by default), HTML content will be sanitized and certain tags (e.g., script and style tags) may be removed for security reasons.

success.description: Indicates whether the Request/Response was successful.

content.description: The scraped content from the URL or search results in various formats, including HTML, XML, JSON, CSV, PDF, images, and plain text. The format may vary based on the content type of the URL being scraped. Expect to receive content as a string, list, dictionary, or other appropriate data structure based on the content type. The content may be sanitized for brevity and safety.

error.description: An error message, if any. Possible error messages include 'Invalid URL', 'Invalid page or page_size', 'Invalid num_results_to_scrape', 'Unsupported content type: {content_type}', and 'Failed to fetch the content'. Often times adjusting paramters resolves these issues.

has_more.description: Indicates whether there are more chunks available for pagination after the current chunk. Increment previous 'page' number and include corresponding 'job_id' to request the next chunk.

job_id.description: The unique job ID for this request. The job ID is used to ensure consistency when requesting chunks from a URL that has been recently scraped. If not provided, a new job ID will be generated. It is recommended to include the same job ID when requesting subsequent chunks from the same URL to retrieve content from the cached snapshot of the original request.

cache_age.description: The response may have been retrieved from an in-memory cache to improve performance. Particularly useful when paginating through large content. The 'cache_age' property indicates the age of the cache in seconds since the content was originally fetched.

page_context.description: The context of the current page (chunk) in relation to the total number of pages (chunks) of response data for a given job. For example, '2/7' means this is the 2nd chunk out of a total of 7 chunks. Important to remember the relationship between page_size and page when thinking about page context. For example, if you set page_size to 10000 and page to 2, you will receive the second 10000 characters of the content. If you set page_size to 5000 and page to 3, you will receive the third 5000 characters of the content, which would be content inside of the 2nd page of 10000 characters. Keeping page_size consisten through paginating a given job will ensure that the page_context is consistent.

notice.description: This notice is a system message meant to convey some additional, potentially important context that may help instruct and inform subsequent actions, and should be observed and considered.
